what: How to use the volkeR package?
title: Introduction
text: First, load package, set plot theme get data.
code: # Load the package library(volker)  # Set the basic plot theme theme_set(theme_vlkr())  # Load an example dataset ds from the package ds <- volker::chatgpt

what: How to generate tables and plots?
title: Introduction
text: Decide whether data categorical metric choose appropriate function: tab_counts() shows frequency tables. plot_counts() generated simple stacked bar charts. effect_counts() calculates test statistics categorical data. tab_metrics() creates tables distribution parameters. plot_metrics() visualised distributions density plots, box plots scatter plots. effect_metrics() calculates test statistics metric data. column selection determines whether analyse single variables, item lists compare correlate multiple variables. Try !

previous_headings: How to generate tables and plots?

code: # A single variable tab_counts(ds, use_private) # A list of variables tab_counts(ds, c(use_private, use_work)) # Variables matched by a pattern tab_counts(ds, starts_with("use_"))

title: Introduction
text: Provide grouping column third parameter compare different groups. metric variables, can compare mean values. default, crossing variable treated categorical. can change behaviour using metric-parameter calculate correlations: table function corresponding plot function parameters pimp result. See function help (F1 key) learn options. example, can use prop parameter grow bars 100%. numbers parameter prints frequencies percentages onto bars.  , effect-functions conduct statistical tests:
code: tab_counts(ds, adopter, sd_gender) # Compare the means of one grouping variable  (including the confidence interval) tab_metrics(ds, sd_age, sd_gender, ci = TRUE) # Correlate two metric variables tab_metrics(ds, sd_age, use_work, metric = TRUE, ci = TRUE) ds |>    filter(sd_gender != "diverse") |>    plot_counts(adopter, sd_gender, prop="rows", numbers=c("p","n")) ds |>    filter(sd_gender != "diverse") |>    effect_counts(adopter, sd_gender)

what: Custom labels: Where do they come from?
title: Introduction
text: Labels used plots tables stored comment attribute variable. can inspect labels using codebook()-function: can set custom new labels labs_apply() providing tibble item names first column item labels second column. 2 missing case(s) ommited. Alternatively, save result codebook(ds) Excel file, change labels manually copy Excel file, finally call labs_apply() revised codebook.
code: codebook(ds) #> # A tibble: 94 × 6 #>    item_name     item_group item_class item_label         value_name value_label #>    <chr>         <chr>      <chr>      <chr>              <chr>      <chr>       #>  1 case          case       NA         case               NA         NA          #>  2 sd_age        sd         NA         Age                NA         NA          #>  3 cg_activities cg         NA         Activities with C… NA         NA          #>  4 use_private   use        NA         Usage: in private… 1          never       #>  5 use_private   use        NA         Usage: in private… 2          rarely      #>  6 use_private   use        NA         Usage: in private… 3          several ti… #>  7 use_private   use        NA         Usage: in private… 4          several ti… #>  8 use_private   use        NA         Usage: in private… 5          almost dai… #>  9 use_work      use        NA         Usage: in profess… 1          never       #> 10 use_work      use        NA         Usage: in profess… 2          rarely      #> # ℹ 84 more rows newlabels <- tribble(   ~item_name, ~item_label,   "cg_adoption_advantage_01", "Allgemeine Vorteile",   "cg_adoption_advantage_02", "Finanzielle Vorteile",   "cg_adoption_advantage_03", "Vorteile bei der Arbeit",   "cg_adoption_advantage_04", "Macht mehr Spaß" )  ds %>%   labs_apply(newlabels) %>%   tab_metrics_items(starts_with("cg_adoption_advantage_")) library(readxl) library(writexl)  codes <- codebook(ds) write_xlsx(codes,"codebook.xlsx")  codes <- read_xlsx("codebook_revised.xlsx") ds <- labs_apply(codebook)

title: Introduction
text: volker-package based standard methods data handling visualisation. can produce outputs handful functions. package just makes code dry - don’t repeat - wraps often used snippets simple interface. Basically, table values calculated two tidyverse functions: count() used produce counts skim() used produce metrics shape data frames, two essential functions come play: group_by() used calculate grouped outputs pivot_longer() brings multiple items format item name becomes grouping variable. Plots generated ggplot(). package provides print- knit-functions pimp console markdown output. make work, cleaned data, produced plots, tables markdown snippets gain new classes (vlkr_df, vlkr_plt, vlkr_tbl, vlkr_list, vlkr_rprt).

title: High-Level Functions for Tabulating, Charting and Reporting Survey Data

title: High-Level Functions for Tabulating, Charting and Reporting Survey Data
text: volkeR package made creating quick easy overviews datasets. handles standard cases handful functions. Basically select one following functions throw data : Charts: plot_metrics() plot_counts() Tables: tab_metrics() tab_counts() Tests: effect_metrics() effect_counts() Reports: report_metrics() report_counts() one best? depends objective: Table plot? plot quick capture, data table better calculations. Functions tables start tab, functions plots plot. doubt, create report-functions. Categorical metric variables? Categories can counted, metric variables distribution parameters mean standard deviation calculated. Functions categorical variables contain counts name, metric metrics. Individual, grouped correlated? Groups can compared (e.g., average age gender) cross-tabulated (e.g. combinations education level gender) providing grouping column third parameter table, plot report functions. calculate correlations show scatter plots, provide metric column set metric-Paramter TRUE. effect-functions calculate effect sizes statistical tests group comparisons correlations. One variable item batteries?. Item batteries often used surveys. item results single variable, variables measured scale (e.g. 1 = 5 = fully applies). summarise multiple items send column selection functions using tidyselect mechanisms starts_with(). Indexes automatically calculated report-functions can explicitly created using idx_add(). Markdown data frame? table functions return data frames can processed . tables print function, output functions can used directly Markdown documents display neatly formatted tables plots. report-functions create tidy interactive tabsheets switch plots, tables, indexes.

title: High-Level Functions for Tabulating, Charting and Reporting Survey Data
text: functions take data frame first argument, followed column selections, optionally grouping column. Examples: Examples: One metric variable: tab_metrics(data, sd_age) One categorical variable: tab_counts(data, sd_gender) Grouped metric variable: tab_metrics(data, sd_age, sd_gender) Grouped categorical variable: tab_counts(data, adopter, sd_gender) Multiple metric variables: tab_metrics(data, starts_with("cg_adoption")) Multiple categorical variables: tab_counts(data, starts_with("cg_adoption")) Hint: replace tab_ plot_ reproduce examples . ’ll find different table, plot report types vignette("introduction", package="volker"). options customize results, see builtin function help (F1 key). deciding whether plot tabulate, whether handle metric counted data, column selections determine following methods called hood. provide two sets columns first two parameters, data crossed. default, second parameter handled categorical variable, resulting grouped tables plots. handling metric variables correlations, set metric-parameter TRUE. (Note: implemented yet.)

code: codebook(data) newlabels <- tribble(   ~item_name,                 ~item_label,   "cg_adoption_advantage_01", "Allgemeine Vorteile",   "cg_adoption_advantage_02", "Finanzielle Vorteile",   "cg_adoption_advantage_03", "Vorteile bei der Arbeit",   "cg_adoption_advantage_04", "Macht mehr Spaß" )  data %>%   labs_apply(newlabels) %>%   tab_metrics(starts_with("cg_adoption_advantage_")) data %>%   labs_store() %>%   mutate(sd_age = 2024 - sd_age) %>%    labs_restore() %>%       tab_metrics(sd_age)

title: High-Level Functions for Tabulating, Charting and Reporting Survey Data
text: prop: Calculating percentages cross tab requires careful selection base. can choose total, row column percentages. stacked bar charts, displaying row percentages instead total percentages gives direct visual comparison groups. ci: Add confidence intervals plot table outputs. index: Indexes (=mean multiple items) can added using idx_add() manually automatically calculated report functions. Cronbach’s alpha added table outputs. effect: sure whether differences statistical significant? One option look non overlapping confidence intervals. addition, effect option calculates effect sizes Cramer’s v Cohen’s d generates typical statistical tests Chi-squared tests t-tests. method: default, correlations calculated using Pearson’s R. can choose Spearman’s Rho methods-parameter.

text: percent: Frequency tables show percentages default. Set FALSE get raw proportions - easier postprocess calculations. digits: Tables containing means standard deviations default round values one digit. Increase number show digits. values: variables desire, denser output must . tables try serve insights maximum show two values one cell, example absolute counts (n) percentages (p), mean (m) standard deviation (sd). Control desire values-parameter.

title: High-Level Functions for Tabulating, Charting and Reporting Survey Data

Set numbers parameter “n”, “p” c(“n”,“p”). prevent cluttering overlaps, numbers plotted bars larger 5%. limits: know create misleading graphs? happens truncate minimum maximum value scale. scale limits automatically guessed package functions (work progress). Use limits-parameter manually fix misleading graphs. box: metric plots can visualise distribution adding boxplots. log: Metric values long tail distributions easy visualise. scatter plots, can use logarithmic scale. aware, zero values omitted log value undefined.

title: Prepare data originating from SoSci Survey — data_clean_sosci
text: data Data frame remove.na.levels Remove residual values factor columns. Either character vector residual values TRUE use defaults VLKR_NA_LEVELS. can also define disable residual levels setting global option vlkr.na.levels (e.g. options(vlkr.na.levels=c("answered")) disable options(vlkr.na.levels=FALSE)). remove.na.numbers Remove residual values numeric columns. Either numeric vector residual values TRUE use defaults VLKR_NA_NUMERIC. can also define disable residual values setting global option vlkr.na.numbers (e.g. options(vlkr.na.numbers=c(-2,-9)) disable options(vlkr.na.numbers=FALSE)). add.whitespace Add whitespace slashes improved label breaks.

Setting metric-parameter TRUE call appropriate functions correlation analysis: Two metric columns: see tab_metrics_one_cor Multiple columns: see tab_metrics_items_cor (experimental)

title: Output a table with distribution parameters — tab_metrics
code: tab_metrics(data, cols, cross = NULL, metric = FALSE, clean = TRUE, ...)

title: Output a table with distribution parameters — tab_metrics
text: data data frame. cols tidy column selection, e.g. single column (without quotes) multiple columns selected methods starts_with(). cross Optional, grouping column (without quotes). metric crossing variables, cross column parameter can contain categorical metric values. default, cross column selection treated categorical data. Set metric TRUE, treat metric calculate correlations. clean Prepare data data_clean. ... parameters passed appropriate table function.

title: Define a default theme for volker plots — theme_vlkr
text: base_size Base font size. base_color Base font color. base_fill list fill color sets least one fill color set. Example: list(c("red"), c("red", "blue", "green")). set can contain different numbers colors. Depending number colors needed, set least number required colors used. first color always used simple bar charts. base_gradient color vector used creating gradient fill colors, e.g. stacked bar plots.

title: Define a default theme for volker plots — theme_vlkr
Define a default theme for volker plots — theme_vlkr
code: library(volker) library(ggplot2) data <- volker::chatgpt  theme_set(theme_vlkr(base_size=15, base_fill = list("red"))) plot_counts(data, sd_gender)
